summary: On December 19, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia entered a final judgment against HUD, ordering the agency to suspend or delay implementation of the Housing Choice Voucher (SFFR) rule for 24 metropolitan areas.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Chicago on Dec. 23, 2016, HUD delayed the implementation of SFFR until at least 2020.  The complaint alleges that HUD failed to adequately consider the impact of the delay on low-income tenants' rental housing market conditions.  In its order, the court also ordered HUD to provide an accounting of the number of units available to voucher holders in each of the 24 metro areas subject to the rule.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, HUD has agreed to the entry of a final rule that requires all PHAs to implement SFFRs by at least two years.  On January 1, 2018, HUD announced that it would suspend or exempt a SAFR designation for 24 metro area PHAs in 24 states, including the Dallas, Texas area, for reasons unrelated to the safety and well-being of the voucher holders.  HUD also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $100,000, which is equal to the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a $50,000 civil penalty.  Additionally, HUD agreed to a preliminary injunction against further violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and to a permanent injunction against future violations of Section 8 of the Exchange Act and Rule 8b2-1 thereunder.  Under the proposed injunction, HUD will have the option of suspending or exempting the SAFR provision from the federal securities laws, or to issue a civil injunctive relief order.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-1-2017 (Dec. 22, 2016).  The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â The SEC's Complaint also alleges that, in a parallel action, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) failed to provide timely and sufficient information to determine whether a specific action is warranted.  Among other things, the Complaint alleges that the Secretary of State's Office failed to inform HUD of the relevant facts of the matter and failed to act on them.   The Complaint charges HUD with violating Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 10(e) of
